title: America's National Parks Store - Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park

images.altText: America's National Park Store
images.title: America's National Parks Store
images.caption: Photo of America's National Park Store in Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center

bodyText: The park store is operated by America's National Parks, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting the educational mission of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park. The park store has a wide range of books, maps, media, souvenirs, and other items available for retail sale. These products complement the interpretive themes you experience when visiting the park. The park stores are located inside Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center and Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center, or you can visit the online park store at Chickamauga & Chattanooga National Military Park - Shop Americas National Parks.
audioDescription: America's National Parks Stores are located within the two park visitor centers, at Chickamauga Battlefield and at Lookout Mountain Battlefield. The store at Chickamauga is lined with bookshelves and kiosks, while the store at Lookout Mountain is integrated into the visitor center lobby. It has a few bookshelves and kiosks as well.
passportStampLocationDescription: Stamps for Chickamauga Battlefield and other units are located within the America's National Parks Store inside Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center. Stamps for Lookout Mountain Battlefield and other units are located within the America's National Parks Store inside Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center as well.

quickFacts.value: Site of the second deadliest battle of the Civil War; Significant battles for control of the gateway city of Chattanooga, Tennessee
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Brown's Ferry Federal Road

images.altText: A park ranger leads a tour of the Brown's Ferry Federal Road
images.title: Tour of Brown's Ferry Federal Road
images.caption: A park ranger leads a tour of the Brown's Ferry Federal Road on Moccasin Bend.

relatedParks.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
relatedParks.name: Trail Of Tears

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: This trace joined the road from Washington, Tennessee, to the Federal Road that crossed the face of Lookout Mountain, thereby connecting the growing hub of Ross's Landing (modern-day Chattanooga) to points west. John Brown, a local Cherokee, claimed the land and ferry across the river, benefiting from the growing trade. Yet in 1838, thousands of Cherokee crossed the road as part of the forced removal to Indian Territory. Just 25 years later, salvation came to the besieged US army in Chattanooga as supplied on the "Cracker Line" crossed over the road.
audioDescription: You are now standing in the gravel lot of the Brown's Ferry Federal Road Trace. There are small signs that denote original sections of the road. Waysides also provide additional information as you walk along the trail.

title: Chickamauga Battlefield Self-Guided Tour Introduction

images.altText: The First Gun at Chickamauga by Alfred Waud
images.title: The First Gun at Chickamauga
images.caption: The First Gun at Chickamauga, by Alfred Waud, depicts the clash at Reed's Bridge on September 18.

bodyText:
“As we are united in life, and they united in death, let one monument perpetuate their deeds, and one people, forgetful of all asperities, forever hold in grateful remembrance all the glories of that terrible conflict which made all men free and retained every star on the nation’s flag.” These words, etched onto the Kentucky Monument along Lafayette Road, commemorate the sacrifices made by those men who fought and died here on Chickamauga Battlefield, and pays tribute to what they accomplished. For three days in September 1863, more than 125,000 Union and Confederate soldiers struggled here to determine the future of our nation. Less than thirty years later, they gathered here once again as reunited citizens of the United States of America. In August of 1890, Congress established Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park, setting aside this land so that future generations could learn about what took place here. 

There are eight stops along this tour route. Follow the route highlighted in your park brochure, or follow the arrows on the tour route signs around the battlefield.
audioDescription: You are now standing just outside Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center.

title: Cravens House

images.altText: Living historians portraying Confederates congregate at Cravens House
images.title: Cravens House
images.caption: Living historians portray Confederate soldiers at Cravens House

bodyText:
The Cravens House is the oldest surviving structure on Lookout Mountain, and was the home of Robert Cravens, a pioneer Chattanooga industrialist. Situated on a shelf-like ledge on Lookout Mountain's eastern slopes, the Cravens House was a major focal point in the Civil War "Battle Above the Clouds," on November 24, 1863. The Cravens House story shows how the Civil War directly affected one man and his family. 

Robert Cravens was an ironmaster, coming to the Chattanooga area in the early 1850s. His iron business consisted of a blast furnace, a foundry, and a machine shop manufacturing mostly railroad engines and freight cars. By the late 1850s, Cravens was an established businessman in the community and was considered wealthy for the period. Deciding to make the Chattanooga area home, Cravens purchased land on the eastern slopes of Lookout Mountain. The original Cravens House, called “Alta Vista,” was completed in 1856 and was a modest one-story dwelling, with six rooms. 

By late summer 1863, the clouds of war had drifted into the small rail town of Chattanooga. In the aftermath of the Battle of Chickamauga, the city became overrun with US troops. Confederates encircled the city from the north end of Missionary Ridge to Lookout Valley. Cravens supported the Confederacy, although, he had strongly opposed secession. On Lookout Mountain, Confederates occupied the summit, mid-slopes, and base. For over a month the Cravens family lived a siege within a siege. Confederate officers lived inside the house with the family, while the enlisted men were encamped all around the front yard. Cravens and his family continued to live in their home even though it had become the Confederate’s main line of defense against a potential attack. Eventually, the constant shelling by US cannon forced the family to leave their home and move to Woods Station, near Ringgold, Georgia.

On the morning of November 24, US General Joseph Hooker with approximately 10,000 men ascended the mountain and swept around the slopes of Lookout Mountain, attacking Confederate General Edward C. Walthall’s brigade of 1,500 Mississippians. By early afternoon, the Confederates had been pushed back beyond the house. During the night, all Confederates were withdrawn from Lookout Mountain and moved to join their other forces on Missionary Ridge.

After the Battles for Chattanooga, the city became the military base of operations for the Atlanta Campaign. With the hustle and bustle of military movement in Chattanooga, many newspaper correspondents came to the area. These correspondents set up their camp in the Cravens House front yard, where they wrote, sketched, and photographed. Though the “White House,” as the soldiers referred to it, had been repeatedly hit by cannon and small arms fire, it was intact after the battle. But during the days following, the house was almost completely stripped away. Much of the house was used as flooring for the soldiers’ and correspondents’ tents and as firewood. Also, many soldiers literally took parts of the house as souvenirs symbolizing their experiences on Lookout Mountain.

The Cravens family returned to Lookout Mountain at the end of the Civil War. Finding practically nothing left of their home, Robert Cravens decided to rebuild the house during 1865/1866. He continued to live in the new house until his death in 1886, and Mrs. Cravens lived in the house until her death in 1896.

In the 1950s, the Cravens House was restored to its present post-Civil War appearance by the Chattanooga Chapter of the Association for Preservation of Tennessee Antiquities. Today, the Cravens House is administered by the National Park Service.
audioDescription: You are standing at the Cravens House, a large two-story, frame structure, with an almost entirely wrap around porch. To the right of the house is the stone dairy, completed in 1862.

multimedia.title: Robert Cravens and the Cravens House

title: Lookout Mountain Battlefield - Point Park Introduction

images.altText: Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center
images.title: Lookout Mountain Battlefield VC
images.caption: Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText:
You are standing at the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center. It is a stone historic building that houses exhibits about the Battles for Chattanooga. the large James Walker painting of the Battle of Lookout Mountain can also be found within the visitor center.

Lookout Mountain Battlefield encompasses approximately 3,000 acres of land on the summit and slopes of Lookout Mountain. Point Park's 16 acres provides overlooks, monuments, and cannon positions interpreting the Battle of Lookout Mountain as well as the other Battles for Chattanooga. 

Please note that there is an entrance fee for Point Park. It is $10/adult, ages 16 and older, kids 15 and younger may enter for free. If you have a National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass, the passholder and three other adults may enter for free.
audioDescription: You are currently standing at the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center. Directly across the street is the large entrance gate to Point Park.

title: Moccasin Bend National Archeological District

images.altText: Bird's-eye view of Moccasin Bend from the Ochs Museum on Lookout Mountain
images.title: Moccasin Bend
images.caption: Bird's-eye view of Moccasin Bend from the Ochs Museum, inside Point Park.

bodyText: Moccasin Bend is a peninsula formed by a prominent bend in the Tennessee Rive rand is directly across the river from downtown Chattanooga. The area contains nationally significant archeological sites that chronicle approximately 12,000 years of American Indian occupation. These sites are associated primarily with Archaic, Woodland, and Mississippian cultural periods. The Trail of Tears National Historic Trail follow sthe route of the Brown's Ferry Road that crossed Moccasin Bend and commemorates the forced removal of Cherokee Indians from their ancestral homelands. Important Civil War-era earthworks and associated resources constructed by US forces are located along Stringers Ridge, which effectively screens most of the Moccasin Bend unit from downtown Chattanooga. The 768-acre district became a unit of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park in 2003.
audioDescription: You are now standing in a large open field, known as the Gateway Site, which is designed to be the entrance, or "gateway" to Moccasin Bend National Archeological District.

title: Orchard Knob

images.altText: Visitors listen to a ranger-led program on Orchard Knob
images.title: Orchard Knob
images.caption: Visitors listen to a ranger-led program about the fighting that took place on Orchard Knob.

bodyText:
In November 1863, the US Army launched a series of attacks to break the siege of Chattanooga. One of the first of these attacks came at a hillside in eastern Chattanooga called Orchard Knob. During the assault on Missionary Ridge, General Ulysses S. Grant stood atop Orchard Knob as he used the vantage point to observe the attack. 

Because the city grew over much of the battlefield, Orchard Knob is one of the best preserved sites from the Battles for Chattanooga, and it is the heard of the Orchard Knob Neighborhood, a vibrant community that surrounds the park.
audioDescription: You are standing atop Orchard Knob, surrounded by US monuments and cannon. Chattanooga is to the west, Lookout Mountain is to the southwest, and Missionary Ridge is to the east.

multimedia.title: The Battle of Orchard Knob - with Park Historian Jim Ogden

title: Orchard Knob Walking Tour - Stop 1: Iron Entrance Gate to Orchard Knob

images.altText: THE CAPTURE OF ORCHARD KNOB, CHATTANOOGA, BY HAZEN'S AND WILLICH'S BRIGADES, DEPLOYED AS SKIRMISHERS
images.title: The Capture of Orchard Knob
images.caption: The capture of Orchard Knob, Chattanooga, by Hazens and Willich's Brigades.

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: Orchard Knob is located between Missionary Ridge and Chattanooga, essentially it was a no-mans-land between Union and Confederate forces in 1863.

title: Orchard Knob Walking Tour - Stop 2: The Fight for the Gateway Begins - Orchard Knob

images.credit: Alabama Department of Archives and History
images.altText: 28th Alabama Infantry's flag with Alabama above a starburst and 28th Regt below.
images.title: 28th Alabama Infantry's Flag
images.caption: This flag was capture during the fighting at Orchard Knob, November 23, 1863.

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: The 28th Alabama and 24th Alabama Infantry Regiments were overwhelmed by superior US forces on November 23, 1863. The assault lasted less than one hour.

title: Orchard Knob Walking Tour - Stop 3: Forward Observation Post - Grant Watches the Miracle at Missionary Ridge

images.altText: Generals Grant, Thomas, and Granger watch the Battle of Missionary Ridge on November 25, 1863
images.title: Battle of Chattanooga by Thulstrup
images.caption: Generals Grant, Thomas, and Granger watch the Battle of Missionary Ridge on November 25, 1863.

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: General Ulysses S. Grant and other US officers watched the Battle of Missionary Ridge from Orchard Knob, which provided a forward observation point for them to be able to see the ridge in its entirety.

title: Orchard Knob Walking Tour - Stop 4: 1st Michigan Engineers Monument

images.altText: The bas-relief on the monument shows engineers bridging the Tennessee River during the campaign.
images.title: 1st Michigan Engineers Monument
images.caption: The bas-relief on the monument shows engineers bridging the Tennessee River during the campaign.

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: The 1st Michigan was the only engineering regiment assigned to the US Army of the Cumberland, only numbering approximately 300 men during the campaign. These men were primarily tasked with building and repairing bridges and railroads. At Chattanooga, a portion of the regiment helped open the much-needed supply line, later dubbed “The Cracker Line” by preparing the needed materials and constructing the pontoon bridges across the Tennessee River at Brown’s Ferry, which was completed in an astounding 8 hours, and at South Chickamauga Creek, near the north end of Missionary Ridge. The amazingly intricate bronze relief on the monument’s face depicts the laying of a pontoon bridge across the river. At the same time, other members of the regiment were engaged in working along the railroad from Chattanooga to Murfreesboro, Tennessee.

title: Orchard Knob Walking Tour Introduction

images.altText: This image shows trees atop Orchard Knob in the 1880s.
images.title: Orchard Knob
images.caption: This photograph of Orchard Knob was taken in the 1880s.

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: Orchard Knob became part of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park between 1892 and 1893.
audioDescription: Orchard Knob is a large grassy knoll, enclosed by a rock wall, with a paved walking path to the top. Large monuments, plaques, waysides, and cannon are located throughout Orchard Knob.

title: Point Park Tour Stop #1 - Entrance Gate

images.altText: Point Park Gate, ca. 1907
images.title: Point Park Gate, ca. 1907
images.caption: Point Park Gate, ca. 1907

bodyText: The Point Park entrance gate is the largest emblem dedicated to the US Army Corps of Engineers in the world. It was completed in 1905.
audioDescription: You are now looking at the entrance gate, which resembles a large castle with two turrets.

title: Point Park Tour Stop #2 - Parrott Gun Overlook

images.altText: 20-Pounder Parrott Cannon
images.title: 20-Pounder Parrott Cannon
images.caption: 20-Pounder Parrott Cannon

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: In late September 1863, members of Confederate Lt. Colonel Edward Porter Alexander's Artillery Battalion scaled the heights of Lookout Mountain. From the summit, they were able to watch the besieged US army. Although too far to reach Chattanooga, the cannon were able to pound away at Moccasin Bend and the Tennessee River on a daily basis.
audioDescription: You are now standing between two large iron cannon that could fire a 20-pound shell. Looking off the mountain, you can see the city of Chattanooga and the Tennessee River below.

title: Point Park Tour Stop #3 - Garrity's Battery

images.altText: Garrity's Battery, ca. 1900
images.title: Garrity's Battery, ca. 1900
images.caption: Garrity's Battery, ca. 1900

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: Although these are two 12-pounder Napoleon cannon are situated here today, in 1863, two 10-pounder Parrott cannon occupied this position.
audioDescription: Before you is a cast iron tablet and two 12-pounder bronze Napoleon cannon. The guns of Garrity's Battery overlook the city of Chattanooga and Chattanooga Valley, directly below you.

title: Point Park Tour Stop #4 - Western Overlook & Wauhatchie

images.altText: Charge of the Mule Brigade
images.title: Charge of the Mule Brigade
images.caption: Mules charge through Confederates during the 1863 Battle of Wauhatchie

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: The Battle of Wauatchie was one of the only "night battles" during the Civil War. The battle was primarily fought over control of the newly opened "Cracker Line," which US soldiers secured the previous day, October 27, 1863.
audioDescription: You are now looking off the mountain to the west. In the distance is Raccoon Mountain and the Cumberland Plateau. Below you is Lookout Valley, where the Battle of Wauhatchie occurred.

title: Point Park Tour Stop #5 - Corput's Battery

images.altText: The Battle of Lookout Mountain by James Walker
images.title: The Battle of Lookout Mountain
images.caption: The Battle of Lookout Mountain by James Walker

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: When General Hooker's US forces assaulted fog-enshrouded Lookout Mountain on the western slope, Captain Max Van den Corput moved his guns from his position on the eastern side of the mountain (Garrity's old position) to this one in an effort to hinder the attack.
audioDescription: You are now standing behind two 12-pounder Napoleon cannon at the site where Captain Max Van den Corput fired on US soldiers attacking the fog-enshrouded Lookout Mountain. Not much can be seen from this position except the wooded and rocky slopes of the mountain.

title: Point Park Tour Stop #6 - Ochs Museum and Observatory

images.altText: 8th Kentucky US Infantry on Point Lookout
images.title: 8th Kentucky US Infantry - Point Lookout
images.caption: Members of the 8th Kentucky US Infantry posed on the northern tip of Lookout Mountain

tags: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park
bodyText: On November 24, 1863, US and Confederate soldiers grappled over Lookout Mountain

title: Point Park Tour Stop #7 - The New York Peace Monument

images.altText: New York Peace Monument
images.title: New York Peace Monument
images.caption: The New York Peace Monument is the tallest in Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park

bodyText: The New York Peace Monument, completed in 1907, is the tallest monument within Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military. It stands at 95 ft. and can be seen from downtown Chattanooga.
audioDescription: Standing 95 feet tall, the New York Peace Monument is circular with bronze plaques of all the New York units' names that participated in the Chattanooga Campaign. Atop the shaft are bronze two soldiers, one US and one Confederate, shaking hands.

title: Signal Point

images.altText: A sunset view from Signal Point with the Tennessee River below
images.title: View from Signal Poing
images.caption: The Tennessee River flows beneath the brow of Walden's Ridge, taken from Signal Point.

bodyText:
As the Tennessee River cuts its way through the Cumberland Plateau, it divides the plateau into two distinctive mountains. It was practically the only high ground in the area controlled by US forces during the siege of Chattanooga between September and November 1863. US soldiers used Signal Point to communicate with the outside world by creating a complex signaling system on portions of high ground along the Tennessee River. Signal Point was the key station receiving and sending messages from the besieged city to Bridgeport, Alabama, thence by telegraph to the North. Once US forces opened the supply line to the city from Brown's Ferry on October 27, 1863, the signal station at Signal Point was primarily used for observing and reporting Confederate troop movements in the area. 

Today, Signal Point is a popular hiking destination. In addition to scenic views of the Tennessee River, Signal Point Reservation is an access point for the Cumberland Trail, which stretches several hundred miles across the Cumberland Plateau.
audioDescription: You are now standing at Signal Point. In front of you is an open wooded area, which leads to the brow of the mountain, overlooking the Tennessee River.

title: Tour Stop #1: Breckinridge's Assault

images.altText: Members of the Washington Light Artillery
images.title: Washington Light Artillery Members
images.caption: Members of the 5th Company of the Washington Light Artillery, taken in New Orleans, circa 1862

bodyText:
On September 20, Confederates Commanded by former US Vice President John C. Breckinridge assaulted and briefly penetrated the US line in this area before turning their attack southward.

The four cannon located at this tour stop represent those of the famed Confederate Fifth Company, Washington Light Artillery from New Orleans, Louisiana.
audioDescription: The tour stop is in a large, gravel parking lot, with four bronze Napoleon cannon, representing Slocumb's Louisiana Battery, pointing south.

title: Tour Stop #2: The Battle Line

images.altText: Monuments along Battleline Road
images.title: Monuments along Battleline Road
images.caption: A carriage of visitors travels along Battleline Road.

bodyText: The line of US monuments extending the length of Battleline Road mark where US troops constructed crude breastworks during the early morning hours of September 20. Secure in their positions, they successfully halted repeated Confederate assaults.
audioDescription: You are now standing among US monuments to the United States Regular Infantry, which fought here during the Battle of Chickamauga.

title: Tour Stop #3: Mix-up in Union Command

images.altText: Larkin Poe stands at his old house site
images.title: Larkin Poe
images.caption: Larkin Poe, a Civil War veteran, stands at the site of his home, which burned during the battle.

bodyText: As officers called for troops to strengthen the left end of the US line, General Rosecrans ordered a division to shift out of its position. Unknowingly, his command created a fatal gap in the line.
audioDescription: You are currently standing in a relatively wooded area near the area where the Confederates broke through the US line.

title: Tour Stop #4: Confederate Breakthrough

images.altText: Alfed Waud sketch of the attack on the Union center
images.title: Attack on the Center
images.caption: This Alfred Waud sketch shows attacking Confederates during the Breakthrough of September 20.

bodyText: Before troops could fill the gap in the US line, the yells of thousands of Confederates pierced the air as they poured across LaFayette Road and through the gap. The breakthrough split the US army.
audioDescription: The log house of the Brotherton family stands at Tour Stop #4, amid the open fields across which gray-clad Confederates charged in 1863.

title: Tour Stop #5: Viniard Field

images.altText: The gravestone of Tabler Viniard
images.title: Tabler Viniard Gravestone
images.caption: Tabler Viniard's final resting place is in the Chattanooga National Cemetery

bodyText:
Step back one day to September 19. Thousands of soldiers, one division at a time, fought back and forth across this field trying to gain control of LaFayette Road. When sunset came, neither side held the road, yet thousands had paid the ultimate sacrifice. 

Tabler Viniard, the father of the family who owned and farmed the land surrounding this tour stop, enlisted in the 1st Georgia Infantry, US. Unfortunately, he passed away in 1864, while stationed in North Alabama. He is buried in the Chattanooga National Cemetery.
audioDescription: You are now standing along LaFayette Road, surrounded by fields and trees. Dotting the landscape are numerous monuments commemorating the struggle that occurred at the Vinidard Farm.

title: Tour Stop #6: Lightning Strikes

images.altText: John Munson, a member of Wilder's Brigade, sits on a horse and is holding a Spencer rifle
images.title: Private John Munson - 72nd Indiana
images.caption: Pvt. John Munson of the 72nd Indiana Mounted Infantry astride his mount holding his Spencer rifle.

bodyText: US Colonel John T. Wilder's brigade of mounted infantry, armed with Spencer repeating rifles, halted a portion of the attacking Confederates. The "Lightning Brigade" had the only US success on this part of the Battlefield.
audioDescription: You are now standing at the Wilder Brigade Monument, which is open seasonally for you to climb the circular staircase inside to get a bird's-eye view of this portion of Chickamauga Battlefield.

title: Tour Stop #7: Rout of the Union Right

images.altText: The wounding of General Hood
images.title: The Wounding of General John B. Hood
images.caption: Confederate General John B. Hood was wounded just north and east of Tour Stop #7.

bodyText: Confederate soldiers swept out of the woods and into the fiels in what one commander called "a scene of unsurpassed grandeur." This attack collapsed the US right, forcing the defenders, including US General Rosecrans, to flee.
audioDescription: You are currently standing in a large, open field through which the Confederates attacked US soldiers on prominent rise to the west.

title: Tour Stop #8: Horseshoe Ridge and Snodgrass Hill

images.altText: Veterans of the 2nd Minnesota Infantry gather around their monument on Horseshoe Ridge.
images.title: Veterans of the 2nd Minnesota Infantry
images.caption: Veterans of the 2nd Minnesota Infantry gather around their monument on Horseshoe Ridge.

bodyText: US soldiers held the ridge throughout the afternoon, repulsing repeated Confederate assaults. As darkness fell, one final assault revealed the remaining US troops had slipped away to Chattanooga. After three days of fighting, the Confederate Army of Tennessee was victorious.
audioDescription: You now stand atop Horseshoe Ridge, a wooded ridgeline pocked with numerous monuments where the US Army of the Cumberland made its final stand during Chickamauga.
